items.title: 1X CEO Defends Neo Robot’s Safety, Teleoperation in Your Home and More | WSJ
items.author: The Wall Street Journal
items.content:
<article>Neo is a home humanoid robot built by 1X Technologies. Since its announcement, many have wondered what exactly Neo can—and can’t—do on its own. Ahead of launch, WSJ’s Joanna Stern sat down with the company’s CEO, Bernt Bornich.

Chapters:
0:00 1X Neo’s CEO
0:41 Neo launch plans
3:23 Neo’s unique body
8:04 Why build robots that look like humans?
11:05 What Neo will do 
11:49 Teleoperation vs. autonomy 
16:17 Can Neo unload the dishwasher by itself?
21:22 Neo’s safety 
27:16 The future of robotics and Neo

Tech Things With Joanna Stern
Everything is now a tech thing. In creative and humorous videos, WSJ senior personal tech columnist Joanna Stern explains and reviews the products, services and trends that are changing our world.

#1X #Robotics #WSJ</article>

items.title: Unions and Capitalism: The Uneasy Alliance That Shaped America | WSJ
items.author: The Wall Street Journal
items.content:
<article>American capitalism has grown hand in hand with the union movement and organized labor. From early railroad strikes in the 19th century and the 1935 National Labor Relations Act to rise of the UAW and modern union drives at large companies like Starbucks, WSJ explores how the labor movement shaped how industry operates in the U.S.

Chapters:
0:00 The union movement
0:44 The rise of unions
2:47 The fall of unions
5:40 The reinvention of unions 

News Explainers
Some days the high-speed news cycle can bring more questions than answers. WSJ’s news explainers break down the day's biggest stories into bite-size pieces to help you make sense of the news.

#Unions #Capitalism #WSJ</article>

items.title: Federal Reserve Cuts Rates: Here’s What to Watch Now
items.author: The Wall Street Journal
items.content:
<article>The Federal Reserve cut interest rates for the second time this year, although Chair Jerome Powell said a third cut is “not a foregone conclusion.” WSJ’s Nick Timiraos explains the central bank’s split outlook. 

#wsj #thewallstreetjournal #federalreserve</article>

items.title: Why the U.A.E. Is Building a $5B Casino in the Gambling-Free Gulf | WSJ Breaking Ground
items.author: The Wall Street Journal
items.content:
<article>Las Vegas giant Wynn Resorts is building a $5 billion resort that will be the U.A.E.'s first casino. The project is rising on Al Marjan Island, a man-made archipelago in the northernmost emirate, Ras Al Khaimah. Some experts question the project’s long-term prospects and wonder whether competition from tourism powerhouses like Dubai and Abu Dhabi could hurt this new casino.

WSJ examines the megaproject and examines whether building a casino in a deeply conservative society could be a massive mistake. 

Chapters:
0:00 U.A.E.’s first casino
0:31 The project and why it matters
1:59 Why Ras Al Khaimah?
4:24 The long-term vision 
5:39 Wynn’s expansion plan

Breaking Ground
Breaking Ground digs into megaprojects around the world, uncovering what these developments might mean for the surrounding region and the ultimate costs.

#UAE #Casino #WSJ</article>

items.title: Inside Gaza's 'Yellow Line' as U.S. Weighs Plan to Split Enclave
items.author: The Wall Street Journal
items.content:
<article>WSJ’s Dov Lieber reports from Gaza as the U.S. considers a plan to divide it into separate zones, with reconstruction only taking place on the Israeli-controlled side.

#Israel #Hamas #WSJ</article>

items.title: I Tried the First Humanoid Home Robot. It Got Weird. | WSJ
items.author: The Wall Street Journal
items.content:
<article>The 1X Neo is one of the first humanoid robots built for your home and is equipped with full AI software. For $20,000, you can pre-order X1’s Neo now with delivery set for 2026. But a company representative might need to peer into your home, via Neo’s camera eyes, to help get things done. 

WSJ’s Joanna Stern spent time with it—and its creator—to see what it can really do and how much it still requires a human operator’s help.

Chapters:
0:00 The first humanoid home robot
0:37 Neo’s body (hardware) and safety challenges
3:27 Neo’s brain (teleoperation vs. autonomy) 
7:11 Neo’s usefulness vs. privacy tradeoff
8:11 Neo’s future 

Watch the full interview with 1X CEO Bernt Bornich here: https://youtu.be/NIHU7Y8-8k4

Tech Things With Joanna Stern
Everything is now a tech thing. In creative and humorous videos, WSJ senior personal tech columnist Joanna Stern explains and reviews the products, services and trends that are changing our world.

#Tech #AI #WSJ</article>

items.title: You’ve Stolen the French Crown Jewels. Now What? | WSJ
items.author: The Wall Street Journal
items.content:
<article>It took the Louvre Museum thieves a little under seven minutes to steal the priceless French crown jewels from the museum in Paris. But it could take them a lot longer to make any profit from them. WSJ spoke with an art detective to learn the decisions the thieves may face if they’re looking to profit from the Louvre heist and what fingerprints could be left behind. 

Chapters:
0:00 Profiting off the Louvre heist
0:40 Option 1: keep the jewels intact
1:24 Option 2: breaking them down and selling parts
3:28 Fingerprints in the stones
4:20 The thieves getting cold feet?

News Explainers
Some days the high-speed news cycle can bring more questions than answers. WSJ’s news explainers break down the day's biggest stories into bite-size pieces to help you make sense of the news.

#Louvre #Heist #WSJ</article>

items.title: The Fragile Israel-Hamas Cease-Fire: Two Families’ Search for Remains | WSJ
items.author: The Wall Street Journal
items.content:
<article>The bodies of Israeli hostages who remain in Gaza are at the center of a fragile cease-fire between Israel and Hamas. The U.S.-brokered ceasefire set clear terms: hostages and bodies would be returned, while Israel eased military operations and released Palestinian prisoners.  

WSJ follows two families on a journey for closure as the delicate truce hangs in the balance.

Chapters:
0:00 Israel-Hamas cease-fire
1:17 Ruby Chen’s son
2:23 The Haimi family’s efforts
3:32 U.S. efforts to return bodies to families 
5:18 A funeral

#Israel #Hamas #WSJ</article>

items.title: Why the U.S. Is Flying Bombers Near Venezuela
items.author: The Wall Street Journal
items.content:
<article>The U.S. sent B-1 bombers to the Caribbean just a week after flying B-52 bombers near Venezuela. WSJ’s Shelby Holliday explains how the Pentagon is stepping up its show of force.

#Venezuela #Trump #WSJ</article>

items.title: The $190K ‘Flying Car’ That Doesn’t Require a Pilot’s License | WSJ Tech Behind
items.author: The Wall Street Journal
items.content:
<article>Electric vertical takeoff and landing aircrafts, or eVTOLs, promise a futuristic vision of the world. One company, Pivotal, is taking a different approach with an eVTOL looks different from the rest of the market. Their ultralight consumer eVTOL weighs just 348 pounds, has eight propellers and does not require a pilot’s license to operate. 

WSJ explores how Pivotal’s ultralight eVTOL works.

Chapters:
0:00 Pivotal’s eVTOL
0:37 The physical aircraft
3:10 Flight controls and software
5:14 Applications and challenges

Tech Behind 
'The Tech Behind' explores the amazing engineering, computing, science and algorithms that power our favorite tech.

#eVTOL #Tech #WSJ</article>

items.title: Who is Japan’s New Female Prime Minister?
items.author: The Wall Street Journal
items.content:
<article>Sanae Takaichi becomes Japan’s first female prime minister. WSJ’s Jason Douglas explains who she is and why she’s likely to hit it off with President Trump.

#Japan #Trump #Shorts</article>

items.title: Louvre Heist: How Thieves Stole ‘Priceless’ Jewels in Broad Daylight | WSJ
items.author: The Wall Street Journal
items.content:
<article>Thieves broke into France’s Louvre Museum in Paris, stealing crown jewels and prompting the world’s most visited museum to be evacuated. WSJ explains how the Louvre Museum robbery unfolded and why French authorities are in a race against time to recover the jewels. 

Chapters:
0:00 Louvre Museum robbery
0:14 How the heist unfolded
0:51 What was stolen
1:12 Historical heists

#Louvre #Heist #WSJ</article>
